div.p: B53/4503, unit 185, VPRS 1189 inward registered correspondence, VA 856 Colonial Secretary's Office, Public Record Office, Victoria.

Transcribed 4.9.92. To proof.
See also J. Duerdin to Botanic Gardens Committee, 2 May 1853, and J. Balmain to J. Foster, 14 September 1853. No 53/78

I have the honor to enclose for the consideration of His Excellency the Lieutenant Governor a copy of a Letter received from Mr Jno Duerdin offering for sale, two Green Houses which have lately arrived from England per the "Cherusker".
The Argus, 29 April 1853, recorded the arrival of Cherusker from London.

With reference to the same I have the honor to state that I have inspected the designs for these Houses and am of opinion that if erected they would be a very great ornament as well as a useful addition to the Gardens and from the Invoices which I have also seen I believe the price to be only the actual cost.
I beg therefore to Suggest that these Green Houses be purchased for erection in the Gardens the amount requisite for such purchase to be provided by Supplementary Estimates for 1853
Requesting the favor of your early reply.

On 23 May 1853 La Trobe stated: 'I regret that I cannot feel justified in incurring the expense'. He then asked 'what is the cost' and was told, 'Mr Duerdins letter states some where about £600'.
MS annotation by unknown: 'the garden Committee never meet now or I would have referred [...] to them'.
On 11 May La Trobe asked: 'Is it deemed probably that the Leg. Council would sanction the step?' The matter was referred to the Auditor General and G. Rusden, Acting Auditor General, reported: 'There is no provision at present in the absence of the Auditor General the tone of the Legislature, when a proposal for a vote is made to it can scarcely perhaps be commented upon: more especially as a new element of nearly the same number of elected members as the house has [...] next session'.
